request_pathways.name: Authorization to Use or Disclose Health Information (2019 scan)
Authorization for Use or Disclosure of Health Information (2007 text PDF)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic HIPAA authorization form (image-only scan) from the medical records page and must print, hand-fill, and submit it with no documented electronic submission option.

red_flags: CD as only electronic delivery method — obsolete technology that may limit HIPAA Right of Access
Form 2 requests Social Security Number, which is unnecessary and creates identity-theft risk
Form 2 has blank revocation address, effectively nullifying revocation instructions
Two competing forms on the same page with no guidance on which is current
bright_spots: Form 1 explicitly addresses patients requesting their own records with format choices
Opt-out exclusion model for sensitive record categories (HIV, substance abuse, mental health) is patient-friendly
Form 1 eliminated SSN requirement present in the older Form 2
Comprehensive patient rights language in both forms

findability.rationale: Level 3: Forms are publicly linked from the medical records page and findable via web search, but two competing forms with no guidance on which is current and a cryptic filename on Form 2 require moderate effort and create confusion.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — neither form has fillable fields, the primary form (Form 1) is an image-only scan inaccessible to screen readers, and no electronic submission pathway (fax, email, or portal) is documented on the forms.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate but with notable problems — Form 1 is cramped on a single page with weak visual hierarchy; Form 2 has better organization but contains a garbled legal citation, unnecessary SSN field, and dense footnotes with legal prose.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — both forms are generic third-party authorization forms, though Form 1 includes explicit patient self-access language and format choices that partially accommodate individual access.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may exceed what law requires — CD-only electronic delivery may limit HIPAA Right of Access, Form 2 collects unnecessary SSN, no fee disclosure, and blank revocation address on Form 2 undermines patient rights.

overall.summary: Natividad Medical Center provides a minimally functional but outdated patient access experience through generic authorization forms that lack fillable fields, digital submission options, and a dedicated patient access pathway.
